abstract: Lisa Sanders column on whether hallucinations, facial rigidity and stiff gait that Dickens gives to Ebenezer Scrooge in A Christmas Carol would suggest modern diagnosis; says symptoms perfectly describe Lewy body dementia, which lies at intersection of Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease; photo; drawing (L)
snippet: Lisa Sanders column on whether hallucinations, facial rigidity and stiff gait that Dickens gives to Ebenezer Scrooge in A Christmas Carol would suggest modern diagnosis; says symptoms perfectly describe Lewy body dementia, which lies at intersecti...
lead_paragraph: A lonely old man sits at home one Christmas Eve and has a series of unexpected visitors: the restless spirit of his long-dead business partner, followed by the ghosts of Christmas Past, Present and Future. By morning, this wretched, miserly recluse has been transformed into the season's icon of exuberant celebration. This is, of course, the story of Ebenezer Scrooge -- the way Charles Dickens wrote it in his novella "A Christmas Carol." But there's another way to tell this familiar tale: an elderly man with no known medical problems has a sudden change in mental status characterized by confusion and vivid hallucinations involving friends and relatives, which leaves him in a state of trembling mania and uncharacteristic euphoria. This also describes Ebenezer Scrooge -- but as a doctor might see him. What caused these extraordinary symptoms? a doctor might ask. Could some pathological process have accounted for Scrooge's remarkable experience?

abstract: Discouraging results from a new study speak to the desperate need for effective new treatments for Alzheimer’s.
snippet: Discouraging results from a new study speak to the desperate need for effective new treatments for Alzheimer’s.
lead_paragraph: More and more often, it seems, drugs that were widely thought to be effective against serious illnesses turn out to show little or no value when tested in large, impartial clinical trials insulated from drug company influence. The latest example is a class of drugs known as atypical antipsychotics that are commonly used to soothe agitation, delusions and aggression in people with Alzheimer’s disease.
headline.main: An Alzheimer’s Treatment Debunked
headline.print_headline: An Alzheimer’s Treatment Debunked

abstract: More and more often, it seems, drugs that were widely thought to be effective against serious illnesses turn out to show little or no value when tested in large, impartial clinical trials insulated from drug company influence. The latest example is a class of drugs known as atypical antipsychotics that are commonly used to soothe agitation, delusions and aggression in people with Alzheimer's disease.      A government-sponsored study published in The New England Journal of Medicine last week found that the drugs are no more effective than placebos for most patients and carry troubling side effects, like sedation and confusion.
snippet: More and more often, it seems, drugs that were widely thought to be effective against serious illnesses turn out to show little or no value when tested in large, impartial clinical trials insulated from drug company influence. The latest example i...

abstract: Researchers report that drugs commonly used to soothe agitation and aggression in people with Alzheimer's disease--Eli Lilly's Zyprexa, AstraZeneca's Seroquel and Janssen Pharmaceutical's Risperdal--are not effective and put them at risk of serious side effects; report challenges current practice so sharply that it could quickly alter prescribing habits; about third of about 2.5 million Medicare beneficiaries in nursing homes in United States have taken these medications; spokesmen for three manufacturers note that those drugs were not approved by Food and Drug Administration for use in Alzheimer's patients, nor were they marketed for that purpose; study is published in The New England Journal of Medicine (M)
snippet: Researchers report that drugs commonly used to soothe agitation and aggression in people with Alzheimer's disease--Eli Lilly's Zyprexa, AstraZeneca's Seroquel and Janssen Pharmaceutical's Risperdal--are not effective and put them at risk of seriou...
lead_paragraph: The drugs most commonly used to soothe agitation and aggression in people with Alzheimer's disease are no more effective than placebos for most patients, and put them at risk of serious side effects, including confusion, sleepiness and Parkinson's disease-like symptoms, researchers are reporting today.

abstract: Dr Elissa Ely Cases column describes woman who is suffering from dementia; says that dementia releases essential self and people who are calm personalities remain calm through mental decline; drawing (M)
snippet: Dr Elissa Ely Cases column describes woman who is suffering from dementia; says that dementia releases essential self and people who are calm personalities remain calm through mental decline; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: I'm waiting by the nursing station with a million things to do when an elderly woman on the unit wanders by. I've noticed her before; she's implacable, incontinent and undistressed by the noise and smells of dementia. She doesn't fight her pills and is no troublemaker to the nursing staff. They paint her nails.
headline.main: In Dementia, Can We Wander Toward Peace?

snippet: Dementia releases the essential self; we wander backward uncontrollably and become more of what we already were.
lead_paragraph: I’m waiting by the nursing station with a million things to do when an elderly woman on the unit wanders by. I’ve noticed her before; she’s implacable, incontinent and undistressed by the noise and smells of dementia. She doesn’t fight her pills and is no troublemaker to the nursing staff. They paint her nails.

abstract: Several new studies suggest that diabetes increases the risk of Alzheimer's disease, adding to a store of evidence that links the disorders. The studies involve only Type 2 diabetes, the most common kind, which is usually related to obesity.      The connection raises an ominous prospect: that increases in diabetes, a major concern in the United States and worldwide, may worsen the rising toll from Alzheimer's. The findings also add dementia to the cloud of threats that already hang over people with diabetes, including heart disease, strokes, kidney failure, blindness and amputations.

lead_paragraph: An Associated Press article in Business Day on Tuesday about a federal criminal case accusing Dr. P. abstract: An unusual number of deaths among patients in a large study of Aricept, the most popular drug to treat Alzheimer's disease, is raising concern among federal drug officials and some disease experts. abstract: ''Norman & Beatrice,'' a new play by Barbara Hammond, is subtitled ''A Marriage in Two Acts,'' and this indeed it is: a slice-of-life portrait of a couple as they become familiar with each other through a half century. The onset of Alzheimer's disease in the husband provides an opportunity for Ms. Hammond to celebrate the love and caring that inhere in a happy, 54-year-young marriage. The play is sentimental and clearly affectionate, but it is life sliced thin. Its undoubted warmth and the likability of its title characters will suit undemanding tastes.      We watch the development of the marriage through the wider end of the telescope. The first act is set in 2001, the husband slowly sinking deeper into senile dementia as the wife struggles to keep up with the whirling chaos of his demands and unpredictable behavior. They banter affectionately about golf, about the husband's past career as a local politician, about the children who have long since grown up. In the second act, set 54 years earlier, we see the doubts and joys of the newly married couple, negotiating around their insecurities as they banter affectionately about golf, about the husband's hopes for a career as a local politician, about the first child of the marriage (for she is newly pregnant).

abstract: More and more often, drugs that were widely thought to be effective against serious illnesses turn out to show little or no value when tested in large, impartial clinical trials insulated from drug company influence. The latest example is a class of drugs known as atypical antipsychotics that are commonly used to soothe agitation, delusions and aggression in people with Alzheimer's disease.

abstract: ROTH--Margaret, 88. Died peacefully on Tuesday after a lengthy struggle with Alzheimer's. Beloved companion of Robert Furchgott, Nobel Laureate, wife of the late Stephen Roth. All caring mother of Jane and James Roth, cherished grandmother of Melina and Jack Roth and Jennifer and Michael Sweet. Maggie was an avid gardener and the proud matriarch of the Gallagher clan. Happy St. Patricks Day! In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation, Westchester Chapter.

abstract: GUZY--Harold M., 79, died peacefully on November 27th of complications from Alzheimer's and Parkinson's in Boca Raton Florida. Born in NYC, resided in West Orange NJ, until moving to Boca Raton. Graduate of Cornell University and Harvard Law School. Harold is survived by his loving wife, Rita, four children, grandchildren, and two nieces. Grave-side service at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery in Queens on November 29th at 2:30pm. Donations to Hospice by the Sea of Boca Raton or Alzheimers Association in lieu of flowers.

abstract: MAJZLIN--Freda. Freda (age 92) died August 27, 2006, of natural causes attendant Alzheimer's disease. Beloved wife of the late Gregory, devoted mother of Leonard and Jerome. Cherished grandmother of Lesley Anne and David. Loving sister of Hy Blackbeer and the late Esther Fox. Graveside service and interment will be private. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made in her memory to: George School, Bucks County, PA or the Public Theater, NYC or The Alzheimer's Foundation of America, to continue her passionate commitment to education, the theater and the field of geriatrics.

abstract: LEVINE -- Theodore (Ted). January 15. Age 86, of massive stroke after 14 year struggle with Alzheimers. W.W. II combat tank driver, fine teacher, talented, compassionate psychologist, creative camp director, lifelong worker for peace and social justice. Lived with verve and great sense of humor. With wife Charlotte enjoyed tennis, hiking, biking, swimming, sailing, music, art and books. In addition to his wife survived by children Judith (Paul), Jonathan (Beth), grandchildren Jacob (Rebecca), Sara and wonderful caregiver Norma Gesulla. Memorial contributions to New York Alzheimers Association or anti-war organization of your choice.

abstract: MEHLMAN--Frances (Berman, Lane, Krebs), 85, of San Antonio, TX, formerly of Sands Point, NY and Coconut Creek, FL. She died peacefully on November 1, following a long struggle with Alzheimer's Disease. Beloved mother of Dr. Gary Lane and Dr. April Lane Benson, she was also the grandmother of David, Kate, Cheryl, Eric, and Corey, and great-grandmother of Colin and Alia. A funeral service will be held at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave and 65th St, NYC, on Tuesday November 7 at 11:00am. Interment at King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, NJ will follow immediately. The family requests that any donations be made to the Alzheimer's Association of New York.

abstract: NEW YORK — The drugs most commonly used to soothe agitation and aggression in people with Alzheimer's disease are no more effective than placebos for most patients and put them at risk of serious side effects, including confusion, sleepiness and Parkinson's symptoms, researchers said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The drugs most commonly used to soothe agitation and aggression in people with Alzheimer's disease are no more effective than placebos for most patients and put them at risk of serious side effects, including confusion, sleepiness and Parkinson's symptoms, researchers said Thursday.
headline.main: Dementia resistant to drugs, study says - Health & Science - International Herald Tribune
headline.print_headline: Dementia resistant to drugs, study says - Health & Science - International Herald Tribune

abstract: WETTER--Leo P. Of Westbury on May 25, 2006 after a 14 year battle with Alzheimer's Disease. Beloved husband of Denise. Devoted father of Leo, Richard, Scott, Carol Ann, Nancy and Dennis. Loving father-in-law to Donna, James, Christopher and Carolann. Cherished grandfather of 14. Dearest brother to George (Barbara) and Lois Burkett. Leo was the former owner of the Wantagh Hotel. He also had a 20 year career on Wall Street. He will be remembered for his love of his family, music, sun and surf. Reposing at Donohue Cecere Funeral Home, 290 Post Ave., Westbury, NY on Sunday 7-9 PM and Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial Tuesday 10 AM at St. Brigid's RC Church. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations requested to Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation, 5 channel Drive, Port Washington, NY 11050.

abstract: LONDON--Shirley, 87. Of Kirkland Village, Bethlehem, PA, formerly of Malverne, NY, died April 20, 2006 at Kirkland Village. She was the wife of Harold for 64 years who predeceased her on December 14, 2004. Born in Bronx, NY, she was the daughter of the late Hyman & Ida Kriegel. She graduated from Hunter College, NYC, and did charitable work throughout her life. Our wish is for her to be remembered as she was before Alzheimer's disease devastated her mind and body, but not her sense of humor. Surviving: sons, Dr. Richard and his wife Roberta of Allentown, PA, and Philip in NYC; Grandchildren: Dr. Jason and wife Bonnie, Roger and wife Maria, Randie Taylor and husband Steve, and Ilyssa. She was predeceased by her sisters Bella Wexler and Margie Leinwand. Services were held. Contributions: Alzheimer's Assoc., 617-A Main St., Hellertown, PA. 18055.

abstract: GRAD--Janice. (nee Schapiro). Born April 24, 1933, beloved daughter of the late Pearl Rubin, died October 19, after a battle with Alzheimer's and MAI lung disease. An abstract painter, and longtime member of the Art Students League of NY. Janice exhibited in galleries, office buildings and museums in Manhattan and on Long Island. She produced two shows at Lincoln Center's Cork Gallery. Nicknamed Jackie, she loved Latin music, ballroom dancing, art museums, antique shows, and flea markets. She will be greatly missed. She is survived by her beloved family, husband, Ian Grad, son Douglas, daughter Joy, grandchildren, Amanda and Harry Grad, sisters Norma Schiff, Corinne Bronson, and Cynthia Rubin, and father Frank Rubin. Her daughter Joy would love to hear from her friends. Contact: joygrad@sbcglobal.net. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in name of Janice Grad to: Art Students League; National Jewish Medical and Research Center; or the Alzheimer's Association.

lead_paragraph: GRAD--Janice. (nee Schapiro). Born April 24, 1933, beloved daughter of the late Pearl Rubin, died October 19, after a battle with Alzheimer's and MAI lung disease. An abstract painter, and longtime member of the Art Students League of NY. Janice exhibited in galleries, office buildings and museums in Manhattan and on Long Island. She produced two shows at Lincoln Center's Cork Gallery. Nicknamed Jackie, she loved Latin music, ballroom dancing, art museums, antique shows, and flea markets. She will be greatly missed. She is survived by her beloved family, husband, Ian Grad, son Douglas, daughter Joy, grandchildren, Amanda and Harry Grad, sisters Norma Schiff, Corinne Bronson, and Cynthia Rubin, and father Frank Rubin. Her daughter Joy would love to hear from her friends. Contact: joygrad@sbcglobal.net. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in name of Janice Grad to: Art Students League; National Jewish Medical and Research Center; or the Alzheimer's Association.
headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAD, JANICE. (NEE SCHAPIRO)
headline.print_headline: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAD, JANICE. (NEE SCHAPIRO)

abstract: Pfizer said yesterday that it would acquire Rinat Neuroscience, a privately held company developing drugs for pain, Alzheimer’s disease and other neurological disorders, to move further into biotechnology. Terms of the deal were not announced, though Pfizer is believed to be paying several hundred million dollars.

abstract: Drawing the interest of some of the largest biotechnology venture capital investors, FoldRx Pharmaceuticals, a drug developer focusing on diseases like Alzheimer’s and cystic fibrosis affected by protein misfolding, raised $43 million in Series B financing.

abstract: KOBREN -- Abraham, M.S. D.D.S. Age 88, on February 16, 2006. Beloved husband of 63 years to Ruth Spevack Kobren, loving father of Susan and Murray Morrison of Fairfield, CT, Leonard and Barbara Kobren of Briarcliff Manor, NY, Roberta and Mark Simon of Scarsdale, NY, and devoted grandfather of Jennifer and Jordan Kanfer, Sarah and Aaron Kleinhandler, Adam and Benjamin Kobren, and Lauren Simon, adored great-grandfather of Noah and Rebecca Kanfer, and beloved brother of Anne Berman. He was a retired dentist of 36 years in White Plains, NY, past President and Trustee of the American Dental Association, Assistant Dean for Admissions, New York University College of Dentistry, and received an honorary Doctor of Science degree from Georgetown University. Dr. Kobren spent his adult life dedicated to dentistry. He was a noted lecturer, writer, innovator and respected mentor to his students and colleagues. He died after an extended battle with Alzheimer's disease. He was predeceased by a son, Robert Martin Kobren. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association. Services Sunday, 10:30 am, from Abraham L. Green and Son, 88 Beach Road, Fairfield, CT, with interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla. Shiva Sunday, Monday and Tuesday, with minyan at 7:30 pm, 3200 Park Avenue, Bridgeport, CT.

abstract: DAVIDSON--Norman, of Jamaica Estates, New York on October 29, 2006, at 81 years of age, after a long battle wtih Alzheimer's disease. Norman was a commercial artist and illustrator, and a pioneer in the early days of network television. For nearly 40 years, Norman was an art director and scenic designer at NBC, where he made vital contributions to such classic shows as ''Howdy Doody,'' The Home Show,'' ''The Eternal Light'' and the ''HuntleyBrinkley Report.'' Prior to his association with NBC, Norman was a scenic designer with the fledgling ABC television network. Norman was an esteemed member of Local 829 of the United Scenic Artists, which he belonged to for over 50 years. Graduate of the Yale School of Drama, class of 1948. While attending Yale, Norman also worked as an actor and technical director at the Cherry Lane Theater in Greenwich Village. Norman was a distinguished veteran of World War II, where he served as a gunnery instructor and technical director on several Army shows. Beloved father of Lawrence, Gary (Josie), and Doreen (Gary Gold). Grandfather of Andrew, Kristin, and Dylan. Norman was predeceased by his beautiful wife of 45 years, Sally, in April 1998. Graveside service will be held at Beth Israel Cemetery in Woodbridge, New Jersey on October 31, 2006. In lieu of flowers, the Davidson family requests that a donation be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation of America.

abstract: SUSSMAN--Sylvia (Rachel). The Medical Staff of Beth Israel Medical Center joins the rest of the hospital community in mourning the passing of Sylvia (Rachel) Sussman, whose generosity enabled us to provide comfort for our sickest patients, improve our clinical services and participate in numerous clinical trials to find cures for a host of ailments. Joined in philanthropic partnership by her late husband Leo, Mrs. Sussman supported several of our programs including those addressing cancer, urology, cardiology, hospice and Alzheimer's Disease. She made a significant difference in the lives of those individuals treated in these areas. We offer our deepest sympathies to her family and loved ones during this difficult time. Harris M. Nagler, MD, Chairman, The Sol and Margaret Berger Dept. of Urology Russell K. Portenoy, MD, Chairman, Dept. of Pain Medicine and Palliative Care Steven R. Bergmann, MD, PhD, Chief, The Thomas Killip, MD Division of Cardiology Todd E. Feinberg, MD, Chief, The Betty and Morton Yarmon Division of Neurobehavior and Alzheimer's Disease Michael C. Grossbard, MD, Chief, The Leo and Rachel Sussman Division of Hematology/Oncology     $(6$)SUSSMAN--Sylvia (Rachel). It is with great sadness that the entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowledges the passing of our dear friend and benefactress, Syliva (Rachel) Sussman. Along with her beloved late husband Leo, Mrs. Sussman generously supported many of the hospital's clinical programs and supportive services including the Leo and Rachel Sussman Division of Hematology/Oncology, the Leo and Rachel Sussman Geriatrics and Alzheimer's Disease Unit, and the Leo and Rachel Sussman Inpatient Unit at Continuum Hospice Care/Jacob Perlow Hospice. Her legacy of generosity and support will forever be linked in perpetuity with Beth Israel. To her sons Bruce and Jay, the entire Sussman family and all who loved her, we extend heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Board of Trustees David J. Shulkin, MD, President and CEO Stephen P. Haveson, MD, President, Medical Board Robert G. Newman, MD, President Emeritus

abstract: ANATOLE--Lucille, 87, of Greenwich, CT, and formerly of Egremont, MA, and Lawrence, NY, died at her home on September 24th, 2006. She will always be remembered as Babs. Beloved wife of David (Tolia) for 66 years, loving mother of Amy Schwab and her husband Jim, and Mark Anatole and his wife Jodi. Devoted Grammy to Kate and Joanna Schwab, and Emily and Carter Anatole. Grammy, we will always remember the ''Happy Times''. Donations to the Alzheimer's Association would be appreciated.

abstract: SHERMAN--Florence. On November 7 at home at age 85. Cherished, beloved and loving wife of Julius (John, Jules, Ginsy) for 62 years; passionately devoted mother of Rita and husband, Jeffrey Seward, and of Ray. NYC high school math teacher, artist, idealist, good friend, she changed the world through her deeds. Cared for magnificently by Dr. Norman Relkin, Dr. Arthur Lebowitz, Dr. David Duffy, and by Selena Baksh. She is always in our hearts. For those wishing to make a donation: NYC Chapter Alzheimer's Assoc, 360 Lexington Avenue, NYC 10017, www.alznyc.org

abstract: AMES--Sue H., 70, October 18th, in Boston, MA, formerly of Riverdale, NY. Born Sue Holtz in Buffalo, NY, attended Vassar College and Harvard Graduate School of Education. Resided in Riverdale until 1994, second grade teacher in the Scarsdale School for 25 years. Sue loved to travel, ski and play piano. Survived by her sons, Zachary of Nelson, BC, and Benjamin of Arlington, MA, his wife Shannon, and children Teddy and Isabel. Former wife of Edward A. Ames. Memorials may be made to Alzheimer's Association, 311 Arsenal St, Watertown, MA 02472.

abstract: Diabetes May Increase Alzheimer's Risk  Several new studies suggest that diabetes increases the risk of Alzheimer's disease. The findings add to the cloud of threats already hanging over people with diabetes, including heart disease, strokes and amputations.   PAGE A15    Shuttle Heads Home  The space shuttle Discovery spent its last full day in space and is scheduled to land this morning at Cape Canaveral, completing only the second shuttle flight since the Columbia disaster in 2003.   PAGE A13    Mexicans Rally for Recount  Several hundred thousand supporters of the leftist presidential candidate demonstrated in support of his demand for a recount of Mexico's July 2 election.   PAGE A3    World Leaders on Energy  World leaders at the Group of 8 summit meeting in Russia issued a statement calling for better investment and governance over energy supplies, and endorsed efforts to prepare for a possible oil shock. They also discussed solutions for intellectual property theft and copyright violations.   PAGE A11    Backdating of Stock Options  A new statistical analysis has shown that nearly a third of companies have used backdated stock options to boost executives' compensation   BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1    Doctor Injured in Blast Dies  The physician suspected of blowing up his $6 million town house on the Upper East Side as a way of taking vengeance on his former wife died from the injuries he suffered in the blast.   PAGE B5    Cuts in Medicare Payments  The Bush administration plans changes that could cut Medicare hospital payments by 20 percent for many complex treatments and new technologies.   PAGE A13
snippet: Diabetes May Increase Alzheimer's Risk  Several new studies suggest that diabetes increases the risk of Alzheimer's disease. The findings add to the cloud of threats already hanging over people with diabetes, including heart disease, strokes and a...

abstract: MALECKI--Alfred85, on July 23, 2006. Son of the late Dora and Gustav Malecki, loving husband of Zenia Berkon Malecki, devoted father of Sophie and Lee Dichter, loving brother of the late Edith Neumann of Uruguay. A brave refugee from Nazi Germany and successfull publishing executive at Crain Communications for 34 years, Al, known to friends as Fredi, showed a lust for life until the end. He will be missed by many. Funeral services 10 AM, Tuesday, July 25, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St. Donations may be made to Alzheimer's Association of New York, 360 Lexington Ave., NY, NY 10017.

abstract: JACOBSON--Alan J., 88, passed away peacefully surrounded by family Monday, December 4th. He is survived by his loving family, wife of 53 years Jeanne R. Jacobson, two daughters, two son-inlaws and four grandchildren. He was preceded in death by brother Walter. WWII veteran, lifelong resident of NYC, freelance photographer. Alan Jacobson was a life force who leaves a legacy of energy, passion and kindness, and his absence will be greatly felt by his family and friends. Memorial service Friday, December 8th, Temple Emanuel, 1 E. 65th Street, 12 noon. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Temple Emanuel or to the Alzheimer's Association.

abstract: REBHUN--Dr. Lionel Earl. Of Boca Raton, FL. formerly of Lake Success, NY passed away February 10 after a long illness. Dr. Rebhun practiced Dentistry in Flushing, NY. He graduated with honors from Columbia University Dental School in 1948. Dr. Rebhun was a member of William Jarvie Society and OKU. Beloved husband of Pearl. Father of Laurence, Kit, Andrew and Dr's Donald and Francine Rebhun. Grandfather of Caroline, Chad, Carl, Nicholas and Coby. Loving brother of Elsa Cohen and Allan. He will be interred at Beth Moses Cemetery on Long Island. Shiva will be at his residence in Florida. Donations can be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

abstract: HIRSCH--Laurence J., Jr., August 13, 2006 in Sarasota, FL, age 77. Beloved husband of Joan, cherished father of Barbara H. Browning, Dr. Laurence J. Hirsch III; loved by two stepchildren, Lynn H. Boyd and James A. Rosenbloom; a sister, Lois H. Meyers; adoring grandfather of seven; lover of boating, stockbroker and owner of Ross & Hirsch; career of 40 years on Wall Street. Graduate of Syracuse University, 1948, degree in Engineering; volunteer at Doctors Hospital for nine years. A truly wonderful, caring man. Services private. abstract: GOLDSTEIN - Charles, 85 years old died on Sunday morning April 23rd due to complications of Alzheimer's disease. He was the beloved husband of Yetta for almost 65 years, the cherished father of Alan, Paul and Mary, and the late Nancy; and the adored and adoring grandfather of Michael and Daniel. Mr. Goldstein, a World War II veteran, was a union organizer from the 1940's until 1990 when he retired. He was President of Amalgamated Local 355 in Queens, NY. The union later became the United Service Workers of America and is now part of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners. Services Wednesday 10AM ''Sinai Chapels'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows, NY.

abstract: Put your hands in the air, and wave 'em like you just don't care; after all, your deodorant is good for another seven days. That's right: a single nighttime application of Lavilin, according to its manufacturer, will keep you odor-free for a week. The product was created by Israeli researchers more than 20 years ago as an alternative to antiperspirants made with aluminum, a metal that has been linked to Alzheimer's disease. Lavilin is nontoxic and contains antibacterial agents like arnica and calendula oil. Participants in clinical trials reported that they smelled fresh despite excessive physical activity and extreme temperatures. Lavilin is sold at health-food stores across the country for $15. Call (800)528-4546.   CELIA ELLENBERG

abstract: LUFRANO--Carmine (Carm). Age 89, died on February 20 after a long struggle with Alzheimer's Disease. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Joan (nee O'Brien), his sister Marie Maier, his brothers Louis (Rosemary) and Edward (Anne), sisters-in-law Rose O'Brien, Anne Kenny, Marie King and Jeanne Lufrano. He was adored by numerous nieces and nephews. Carm was born in New York City and was a lifelong resident. He served in WWII with the U.S. Americal Division in the South Pacific and was decorated for bravery on Guadalcanal. He spent his working career in the textile industry. His charm and wit will be missed by all who knew him. Abiding by his wishes there will be no service.

abstract: LERMAN--Morris (Murray). Of Lake Worth, FL, formerly of Woodmere, NY on February 10, 2006. Beloved husband of 55 years to Blanche (Useloff) Lerman. Loving father of Roberta and Alan Herman and Andy and Judi Lerman. Proud grandparent of Jaime and Daniel Herman and David and Adam Lerman. Brother of Saul Lerman. Retired Chief Executive of a manufacturing firm, Murray served in the Army during WWII. He delighted in his family and friends, went out of his way to make others happy, and was a terrific golfer and pool player. He will be missed deeply by all who knew him. Services Wednesday, February 15 at Gutterman's in Rockville Centre, 516-764-9400. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the Alzheimer's Association.

abstract: EDELSTEIN--Ruth (Schnitzer). Age 82, on June 8, 2006, Rye, NY. Wife of the late Alfred Edelstein; mother of Richard, Charles (Tuck) and Laura Kinyon; grandmother of Asher and Miles. Ruth grew up in New Rochelle and moved to Harrison with Alfred where they raised their family. In recent years they lived together in The Osborn in Rye. Trained in commercial art, Ruth was a homemaker, volunteer, and enthusiastic participant in the worlds of dance and music, painting and ceramics. She will be dearly missed by her family and friends. Memorial contributions welcome to Martha Graham Center of Contemporary Dance and the Alzheimer's Foundation of America. Funeral services Monday, June 12, 4:00 pm at The Osborn, Rye, New York.

Trained in commercial art, Ruth was a homemaker, volunteer, and enthusiastic participant in the worlds of dance and music, painting and ceramics. She will be dearly missed by her family and friends. Memorial contributions welcome to Martha Graham Center of Contemporary Dance and the Alzheimer's Foundation of America. Funeral services Monday, June 12, 4:00 pm at The Osborn, Rye, New York.
headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths   EDELSTEIN, RUTH (SCHNITZER)
headline.print_headline: Paid Notice: Deaths   EDELSTEIN, RUTH (SCHNITZER)

abstract: KNOBLER -- Selma (nee Frankel). Died May 9 at the age of 84 after a long struggle with Alzheimer's. A lifetime educator, she taught nursery school at Downtown Community School and received a Master's Degree from the Bank Street College of Education, where she later joined the faculty and taught early childhood education. She was adored by her many students and advisees. She is mourned by her son, Peter, daughter, Joanna (Posy), her brother, Edgar Frankel, daughter-inlaw, Jane Dissin Knobler, sonin-law, Ira Kawaller, and grandchildren, Daniel Knobler and Ben & Zoe Kawaller. Donations should go to Bank Street College of Education and/or organizations actively opposing Bush Administration policies. A memorial service will be announced.

abstract: A French court found Bob Denard, left, France's best-known mercenary, guilty of mounting a coup in the Comoro Islands off southeast Africa in 1995 and gave him a five-year suspended sentence. Twenty-six accomplices drew lesser sentences. The coup was ended after two weeks when the mercenaries surrendered to the French Army and freed the president they had taken hostage. Mr. Denard, 77, who was born Gilbert Bourgeaud before he gave himself the rank of colonel and a new name, was excused from testifying because doctors said he had Alzheimer's disease. snippet: A French court found Bob Denard, left, France's best-known mercenary, guilty of mounting a coup in the Comoro Islands off southeast Africa in 1995 and gave him a five-year suspended sentence. Twenty-six accomplices drew lesser sentences. The coup ...
lead_paragraph: A French court found Bob Denard, left, France's best-known mercenary, guilty of mounting a coup in the Comoro Islands off southeast Africa in 1995 and gave him a five-year suspended sentence. Twenty-six accomplices drew lesser sentences. The coup was ended after two weeks when the mercenaries surrendered to the French Army and freed the president they had taken hostage. Mr. Denard, 77, who was born Gilbert Bourgeaud before he gave himself the rank of colonel and a new name, was excused from testifying because doctors said he had Alzheimer's disease. He is said to be the model for the lead character in Frederick Forsyth's 1974 novel "The Dogs of War," about a coup staged by mercenaries in a West African country, and he took part in conflicts in Benin, Nigeria, Yemen, Zimbabwe and Congo, formerly Zaire.

abstract: McCULLOUGH--John P. Of Princeton died unexpectedly in his home on Tuesday, June 6, 2006 at age of 81. He was a long-time resident of Princeton and a retired executive from Mobil Oil Corporation in Pennington. He is survived by his wife, Ann Calvert McCullough; three daughters, Sherrill M. Davis of Haverford, PA, Cathryn M. Delude of Andover, MA, and Patricia McCullough of NYC; and three grandchildren, Philip M. Delude, Patricia M. Delude, and Michael Gene Davis. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 10, 2006 at the Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton at 2PM, immediately followed by a reception at the main Windrows Complex. For information, Kimble Funeral Home (609924-0018). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to support research at the Alzheimer's Association.

abstract: VEYSEY--Charles died on April 19, 2006. Born May 6, 1916 Winnipeg, Canada. Graduated from U. of Manitoba, 1937; Harvard Business School, 1939. Served Canadian Army; married Odette Walsh in 1942. Lived in Old Greenwich CT. for 30 years and worked NYC Retail for 40 years as VP, B Altman; President, FAO Schwarz; President, Frederick Atkins. Retired Sanibel, FL in 1982; served as President, BaileyMatthews Shell Museum. Survived by wife Odette, children: Michelle, Michael, Itty, Peter and spouses; 12 grandchildren, two great grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donate to the Alzheimer's Foundation in honor of Odette. Memorial Service to be held at St. Isabel's, Sanibel, FL., on Saturday, May 13, 2:30 PM.

abstract: PEEBLES--Bernice Mosbey, 89. Died on February 18 at Hearthstone Alzheimer's Center in Manhattan after a lengthy illness. Bernice grew up in Catskill, New York. She was a school teacher, elementary school principal and Adjunct Asst. Professor at Pace University. She traveled extensively throughout the world. Viewing will be held on Friday, February 24 at Holy Road Episcopal Church at 10:00 AM and the funeral service will be held immediately thereafter at 11:00 AM at 715 West 179th Street, NY, NY. Bernice will be entombed at Trinity Church Cemetery, at 770 Riverside Drive. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Bernice Peebles Scholarship Fund, UAB-228 C/O Mary Johnson, Albany, New York 12222. For info Benta's Funeral Home, Inc.

abstract: MURPHY--Vincent B., Jr., a former Executive Managing Partner with Salomon Brothers and a senior executive with Merrill Lynch, died at his home in Far Hills, N.J. from complications with Alzheimer's. He was 78. In 1964, he joined Salomon Brothers, and became a General Partner at the young age of 39. At Salomon, Murphy was instrumental in the design and functionality of the trading floor known as ''The Room''. He was an Executive Managing Partner for a number of years before leaving to join Merrill Lynch in 1980. At Merrill, Mr. Murphy was President of Merrill Lynch Capital Resources, Inc. and then Special Assistant to the Chairman. Born in Rochester, New York, Mr. Murphy graduated from Yale University and attended Wharton Graduate School. He served as a marine in the Korean War earning the rank of Major and received the Purple Heart. A devout Catholic, he was anointed a member of the Knights of St. Gregory, Knight and former member of the Board of Councillors of the Knights of Malta and a Knight of the Holy Sepulchre. He served on the Board of Patrons of the Arts of the Vatican Museum and Canova Medal recipient. Murphy was the President of the U.S. Equestrian Team and Director of the National Horse Show and Devon Horse Show, as well as a member of the Board of Overseers of New Bolton Veterinarian Center. Murphy became the first Chairman of Liberty State Park Development Corporation. He is survived by his wife of 53 years Patricia Duffy Murphy; and their six children, Vincent, Patricia, Kevin, Daniel, Michaela, and Karen; twenty grandchildren, and a sister Sheelagh Masterson. The viewing will be at his home on Thursday from 4-8 pm and the mass will be at St. Brigid's Church in Peapack, NJ on Friday at 11 am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Vincent B. Murphy, Jr. Memorial Fund at the Alzheimer's Association, 300 Lexington Avenue, Sixth Floor, New York, NY 10017. For more info please contact Bailey Funeral Home of Peapack. 908-234-0590

abstract: SELIGMAN--Henry J., DDS. 86 years old, died on April 6, 2006. Beloved husband of Elaine (nee Gruber). Devoted father of Bill & Gail Seligman and Ron and Angie Seligman. Cherished grandfather of Hannah and Joel and Abbigail and Rebekah; brother of Walter and Bridget Selby. Dr. Seligman graduated the Class of 1960 from Columbia University Dental and School of General Studies. He had a private practice in Manhattan. He was an active member of Temple Emanuel of Great Neck for many years. Services Friday 11:30 AM at Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Holocaust Memorial Fund, Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, or Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation in Port Washington, N.Y.

abstract: WINCIG--Marie Grant departed peacefully on Sunday September 17th, after a long illness. Loving wife of Bernard Wincig and beloved mother of Wendy Burke Svarre, Jonathan W. Burke, and loving stepmother of Owen Wincig, and Lauren Kline. Devoted grandmother of Grant and Caroline Svarre, Jack and Olivia Burke, Kyle, Ryan and Tyler Wincig, Jacqueline, Rebecca and Danielle Kline. Marie retired from Bloomingdale's as the Fashion Director of Women's Accessories, after 25 years with the company. Her passion for her career was only surpassed by her love for her husband, her children, her grandchildren and all the lives that she touched. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to Alzheimer's Association at www.alz.org or 800-272-3900. Funeral will be held at 11:30 a.m. on Wednesday, September 20th, at Frank E. Campbell, 81st and Madison Ave.

abstract: OSTROM--Dorothy (Dodie) Miller, a life long resident of Greenwich, CT died peacefully in her home after a 20 year struggle with Alzheimer's disease on October 17th, 2006. She was born February 11th, 1919 in New York City to the late Drs. John and Katherine Miller. She graduated from Ethel Walker School and Sarah Lawrence College. Dodie was a noted athlete: she was an avid Equestrian and won many blue ribbons competing in the New York Horse Show at Madison Square Garden. She enjoyed fox hunting and rode with the Greenwich Foxhounds. Dodie was also an accomplished Golfer and competed successfully with the Westchester Fairfield Women's Golf Association. As a member of Round Hill Club, she won the Woman's Club Championship and was several times runner up. She also had a great passion for sailing and won many races with her late husband, Stuart Roesler aboard their boat, ''Amber.'' She also had a great love of gardening and flower arranging and she served two terms as President of The Greenwich Garden Club in 1980 and 1981. In 1950, she was the President of the Round Hill Community Guild. Dodie's father, John Miller, was a doctor in Greenwich and served as Chief of Staff at Greenwich Hospital until his death in 1950. Her mother was the first woman doctor to graduate from Cornell Medical School. Dodie was predeceased by her son John T. Davol and her first husband, Rector T. Davol, MD of Greenwich. She was also predeceased by her late husbands, M. Stuart Roesler and Vincent F. Ostrom. She is survived by her daughter, Gaynor D. Casner of Concord, MA, and her son, Ward M. Davol of Greenwich, CT. She also has 10 grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be at 2 PM on Monday, October 23rd, 2006 at Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, Greenwich, CT. A private burial will precead the service. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Alzheimer's Association, 255 N. Michigan Avenue, Chicago, IL 60601.

abstract: FIRST--Saul Richard, 84 years. Beloved husband of the late Ethel M., nee Bauman. Loving father of Donald (Lynn) First and Mary Kay (the late David) Janiszewski. Proud grandfather of Amy and David First and Sara, Ed and Christine Rose Janiszewski. Great-grandfather of Devon Rose, Logan and Dylan. Dear brother of Dorothy (Ira) Elfenbein, Harry (Lee) First, Anne (Irving) Slaw and the late Mary Kellman. Fond uncle of many nieces and nephews. Funeral Service Saturday 11:00am at BlakeLamb Funeral Home, 4727 W. 103rd St, Oak Lawn, IL. Interment Private. Visitation Friday 2-9pm. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Alzheimer's. Member of Oak Lawn Seniors and JohnsonPhelps V.F.W. Post 5220. Amateur artist, writer and actor. Retired advertising executive at Pakula Co. For info call 708-636-1193 or visit www.mem.com

abstract: LESSER--Saal D. (1924 - 2006). Died at peace of Alzheimer 's Disease on June 13, 2006. He was ever the adoring husband of Deborah (Silverman), doting father of Marc and Elizabeth Lesser, Robin and Chris Cordima, and Nina and Todd Insler and proud grandfather of Danielle, Madeleine, Matthew, Gabriel and Ethan. He served as Director of the Encampment for Citizenship, District Director of the Office of Economic Opportunity under Sargent Shriver and as the Executive Director the N.Y. State Division of Human Rights. Through his consulting firms , Saal Lesser Associates and EEO Compliance Services, he was a respected advisor and tireless champion of equal rights. He served as President of the YM-YWHA of Southern Westchester and as Civil Service Commissioner of the City of Mount Vernon. He was an honored athlete and a true friend. Contributions in his memory would be appreciated by The Southern Poverty Law Center or by Jansen Hospice, Tuckahoe, N.Y. His family and friends will gather to remember him on Sunday, June 18, 2006 at noon at Riverside Chapel 21W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, N. Y.

abstract: Elana Jeanne Cox, the daughter of Susan Fine of Wayland, Mass., and the late Elliot Cox, is to be married today to Bruce Lawrence Levinson, the son of Patricia and George Levinson of Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbi Herman J. Blumberg is to officiate at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.     The bride, 30, is a genetic counselor working on Alzheimer's studies at Weill Medical College of Cornell University in New York. She graduated from Carleton College in Northfield, Minn., and received a master's in human genetics from Sarah Lawrence.

abstract: MACKEN--Maritza Hibbard, the niece and and last surviving first generation relative of her uncle, Filipe Carillo Puerto, the ''Liberator of Mexico,'' died on October 23rd from complications of Alzheimer's Disease. She was 76 years old and lived in New York for 26 years. Her life-long interest was promoting music and the music community. She was a long time member of the Board of the Berkshire Choral Institute in Massachusetts and had previously been on the the Boards of Casita Maria and the Musician's Emergency Fund in New York. In Key Biscayne, where she lived previously, she volunteered helping establish the Miami Symphony Orchestra and the Miami Opera Company in Florida. After President Richard Nixon vacated the Key Biscayne White House, she bought it and adjacent property from him. Many artists in the musical world stayed there and she became a world renowned hostess. She was preceded in death by her son, Gary Hibbard, and leaves her husband, Dr. Daniel Loos Macken, three children, Donald Hibbard of Orlando, Mark Hibbard of Los Angeles, Marisa Seaman of Oakland, CA and four grandchildren. A memorial service and reception will be held on Saturday, November 18th at 11AM at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

abstract: Vernon M. Ingram discovered that a single genetic mutation caused the blood disease sickle cell anemia.
snippet: Vernon M. Ingram discovered that a single genetic mutation caused the blood disease sickle cell anemia.
lead_paragraph: Vernon M. Ingram, a molecular biologist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who discovered that a single genetic mutation caused the blood disease sickle cell anemia, died on Aug. 17 in Boston. He was 82.

abstract: Marina Burke, a daughter of Maria Sperazi Burke and Dr. M. Desmond Burke of New York, was married last evening to Fernando Gomez-Evelson, a son of Felisa Beatriz Evelson and Francisco Carlos Gomez of Buenos Aires. The Rev. David Robb, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the W New York hotel. On Thursday, Rabbi Baruj Miller will perform another ceremony at Mishkan, a Jewish spiritual center in Buenos Aires.      The bride, 37, is a geriatric nurse practitioner and the director of client and clinical services at the Manhattan location of SeniorBridge, a company that coordinates health care at home and other locations for the elderly with chronic conditions like Alzheimer's disease, arthritis and diabetes. She graduated from Barnard and received a master's degree in nursing from Columbia. Her father is professor emeritus of pathology and laboratory medicine at Weill Medical College of Cornell University and retired as the director of clinical laboratories at NewYork Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital.

Desmond Burke of New York, was married last evening to Fernando Gomez-Evelson, a son of Felisa Beatriz Evelson and Francisco Carlos Gomez of Buenos Aires. The Rev. David Robb, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the W New York hotel. On Thursday, Rabbi Baruj Miller will perform another ceremony at Mishkan, a Jewish spiritual center in Buenos Aires.

abstract: MACKEN--Maritza Hibbard, the niece and and last surviving first generation relative of her uncle, Filipe Carillo Puerto, the ''Liberator of Mexico,'' died on October 23rd from complications of Alzheimer's Disease. She was 76 years old and lived in New York for 26 years. Her life-long interest was promoting music and the music community. She was a long time member of the Board of the Berkshire Choral Institute in Massachusetts and had previously been on the the Boards of Casita Maria and the Musician's Emergency Fund in New York. In Key Biscayne, where she lived previously, she volunteered helping establish the Miami Symphony Orchestra and the Miami Opera Company in Florida. After President Richard Nixon vacated the Key Biscayne White House, she bought it and adjacent property from him. Many artists in the musical world stayed there and she became a world renowned hostess. She was preceded in death by her son, Gary Hibbard, and leaves her husband, Dr. Daniel Loos Macken, three children, Donald Hibbard of Orlando, Mark Hibbard of Los Angeles, Marisa Seaman of Oakland, CA and four grandchildren. A memorial service and reception will be held on Saturday, November 18th at 11AM at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

abstract: A city employee was arrested yesterday on charges of grand larceny, accused of stealing about $116,000 from a special education program, officials said. The employee, Sandra McMikle, who has worked for the Department of Education for about 25 years, was assigned to process reimbursement claims for transportation and other supplemental education services. From 2001 to this year, she submitted more than 40 fraudulent claims for services to a fictitious child, investigators said. The claims identified Ms. McMikle’s mother, who suffers from Alzheimer’s disease, as the person to be reimbursed for expenses on behalf of the fictitious child, investigators said. Ms. McMikle told investigators that she had “tried it once to see if it would work,” then began submitting claims regularly, a report said. The city paid the claims until January, when Ms. McMikle’s colleagues became suspicious of awkward wording and obsolete case numbers in the documents, the report said. Ms. McMikle told investigators that her mother was unaware of the fraudulent claims, the report said. She pleaded not guilty at her arraignment yesterday. A spokeswoman for the Department of Education, Kelly Devers, said, “We are taking appropriate steps to terminate her employment.”.

abstract: BUSH--Irving T. Esq., 95, a veteran of World War II, died in his sleep Sunday AM in NYC. He suffered from Alzheimer's disease. During WWII, he served heroically in the Philippine Islands. An attorney at the time, having graduated 1st in his class from NYU Law School, and a graduate of Union, he then served on the Island of Japan during its reconstruction under General MacArthur, assisting in drafting the law of Bankruptcy and setting up Japan's Government. After his service, Irving returned to NYC to practice law, specializing in Labor Law & Real Estate. He invested heavily in NY West Village real estate. Nephew of Irving T. Bush, the President of the NY Bush Terminal Co.. He is survived by his wife, Virginia Casey Bush of Greenwich Village, NYC, his sister Barbara Bush Denson of Hebron, OH, and his brother Capt. James Ter Bush, USN (Ret) of Naples FL. In lieu of flowers, send donations to Cabrini Hospital, Att: Mary Cook, 227E 19th St. New York, New York 10013.

abstract: RICE--Christine C. (nee Carroll) of Garden City, NY on March 15, 2006. Beloved wife of 52 years of Laurence J. Rice. Loving mother of Laurence, Louis, Timothy, Paul, Mary Ann, Ellen, Kathleen, Christine, Elizabeth and Sheila. Adored grandmother of Kevin, Brian, Denis, Paul, Ellen, Julia, Mary, William and David. Cherished sister-in-law of Maura Murphy, Charles E. Rice and the late James B. Rice. Loving mother-in-law of Cheryl, Jana, Sheila, Owen and Michael. Daughter of the late Walter F. and Mary Carroll. Proud graduate of the College of Mount St. Vincent (1949). The family will receive friends at Fairchild Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, NY Thursday 7-9 p.m., Friday 2-4 p.m. and 7-9 p.m. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:45a.m. at St. Joseph's Catholic Church, Franklin Avenue, Garden City, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Alzheimer's Association, Long Island Chapter, 3281 Veterans Memorial Hwy, Suite E-13, Ronkonkoma, NY 11779.

abstract: BASTIEN--James William. A loving husband and father, and a passionate piano pedagogue and musician, passed away on December 7, 2005, in La Jolla, California. During his long career, Jim became internationally known through his contributions to piano teaching, composing, writing, adjudication, and performing. With more than 300 publications to his credit, the Bastien name has become synonymous with innovative piano pedagogy. Jim was born in Bellingham, Washington, on April 10, 1934. His father, Clarence, was musical and played the violin. His mother, Dorothy, was a writer and a high school Latin and journalism instructor. After living in Seattle and Florida, the family moved to Portland, Oregon, where Jim began his piano studies with Frances Mulkey North. Subsequently, Jim studied with the late Ariel Rubstein, the late Louis Artau, and the late Gyorgy Sandor. Jim received his undergraduate and Master's degrees from Southern Methodist University. He was a former member of the faculties of Notre Dame University, Tulane University, Loyola University (New Orleans), and the summer faculties of Tanglewood and the National Music Camp at Interlochen, Michigan. Jim met his wife Jane Smisor in New Orleans in 1960. They performed as the duo-piano team, Smisor and Bastien. In addition, Jim was a Columbia Artist accompanist whose collaborative career included appearances with Richard Tucker and John Alexander. During this time Jim and Jane started writing music to address the needs of their students. This was the beginning of the Bastien piano books that have inspired so many piano students and teachers. The Bastien piano books have been published worldwide by the Neil A. Kjos Music Company since 1963 and are now translated into 14 languages. In 1999, The Music Teachers National Association presented Jim and Jane with the Lifetime Achievement Award, the association's highest honor, in recognition of their outstanding career in music and contribution to the music profession. In 1990, Jim was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease and, for the past fifteen years, he was cared for at home. Jim is survived by his wife, Jane Smisor Bastien; his two daughters, Lisa Bastien Hanss and her husband Basil, and Lori Bastien Vickers and her husband Eric. There are four grandchildren, Katie and Julie Hanss and Abby and Riley Vickers. A Memorial Concert will be held at the La Jolla Presbyterian Church on Saturday, January 28, 2006, at 2 P.M. where Jim's former student, Dr. Robert Roux, chair of the piano department at Rice University, Houston, Texas, will perform. A reception will follow immediately in the church fellowship hall. The family suggests donations to one of the following organizations: UCSD Foundation to benefit the Alzheimer's Disease Research Center, 9500 Gilman Drive, MC0696, La Jolla, CA, 92037-0696; The Musical Merit Foundation of Greater San Diego C/O Mr. Kenneth Bullock Treasurer 3593 Fifth Ave. San Diego, CA 92103.

abstract: STONE--Robert J., a prominent public relations professional, died December 27 following a series of strokes. He is survived by his daughter, Judith Stone-Goldman; sonin-law, Allan Goldman; grandsons, Jonathan and Matthew Markowitz; sister, Ruth Lieberman; and companion, Jane Yendell. Mr. Stone was pre-deceased by his wife of 50 years, Shirley, and his oldest daughter, Barbara. In addition to his 50-year public relations career, Mr. Stone was a passionate supporter of firefighters. He was named an Honorary Battalion Chief of the Fire Department of New York and was a member of the Board of Trustees of the New York City Fire Museum. The funeral will be Tuesday, January 2, at 10:00 am, at Weinstein Memorial Chapel in Yonkers, NY. Burial will be in the family plot at Montrepose Cemetery in Kingston. The family will receive guests at Mr. Stones residence for shiva on Wednesday, January 3, and Thursday, January 4, from 7 PM to 9 PM. In lieu of flowers, the family asks for contributions to Hearthstone Alzheimers Care (Attn: Sharon Johnson; 23 Warren Avenue, Suite 140, Woburn, MA 01801); the New York City Fire Museum (278 Spring Street, New York, NY 10013); or a charity of your choice.

abstract: Bush Abandons Phrase 'Stay the Course' on Iraq  The White House says that President Bush is no longer using the phrase ''stay the course'' when speaking about the Iraq war, in a new effort to emphasize flexibility in the face of some of the bloodiest violence there since the American-led invasion in 2003.   PAGE A14    Hevesi Broke Law, Panel Says  A state ethics panel has accused Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi of breaking the law by using state employees to chauffeur his wife, referring the matter to the Legislature.   PAGE B1    Giants Win Dallas Showdown  Tiki Barber rushed for 114 yards and the Giants moved into first place in their division, beating the Cowboys, 36-22.   SPORTSTUESDAY, PAGE D1    Portraits of Alzheimer's  Self-portraits by William Utermohlen, an American artist in London, starkly reveal his descent into dementia.   SCIENCE TIMES, PAGE F5    Enron's Ex-Chief Sentenced  Jeffrey K. Skilling, Enron's former chief executive, was sentenced to more than 24 years in prison for the fraud and conspiracy that led to the company's bankruptcy.   BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1    SPECIAL TODAY    Retirement  A corporate buyout package can offer a new shot at the working life. After taking the money, a pilot now owns an office-supplies franchise, proving a career switch in midlife is highly achievable.   SECTION G

lead_paragraph: Vernon M. Ingram, a molecular biologist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who discovered that a single genetic mutation caused the blood disease sickle cell anemia, died on Aug. 17 in Boston. He was 82.

abstract: GULDEN--Charles Jr., a retired food executive, passed away on December 14th in Stamford, CT. He was born in New York City on November 6, 1934. After suffering from Alzheimers for several years, Mr. Gulden had a short bout with cancer. Mr. Gulden was a graduate of the Hotchkiss School and then served in the Korean War. He then taught at the Harvey School, which was followed by a career in the food industry as an executive with Charles Gulden, Inc., the maker of Gulden's Mustard, which was founded in 1862 by his great grandfather, and later with American Home Products. In the early 1980's, Mr. Gulden was featured in several television ads for Gulden's. Throughout his life, he was an avid boater and reader. He was also a dedicated volunteer for the Hotchkiss School for many years: first as a class agent, then as Chairman of the Annual Fund, and finally as a member of the School's Board of Trustees. Mr. Gulden is survived by his beloved wife, Leonetta Vernon, of Stamford; his son, Charles F. Gulden, daughter-in-law, Jennifer Gulden and granddaughters, Whitney and Abigail Perry Gulden of New Canaan; his brother, Michael, of Palm Beach as well as his former wife, Katherine Gulden of Ponte Vedra Beach. A Memorial Service will be held at the Hotchkiss School Chapel on January 20, 2007. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Charles Gulden Jr. Endowed Annual Fund at the Hotchkiss School, Lakeville, CT.

abstract: Allied Arts  TUESDAY -- The free guides, advocacy and research programs of the Alliance for the Arts will benefit from a dinner at the Rainbow Room that begins with drinks at 6:30. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 947-6340.    For Young Tappers  TUESDAY -- Ben Vereen will be the host of a cocktail party and performance, beginning at 6 p.m., at Cielo, 18 Little West 12th Street, to aid scholarships given by the American Tap Dance Foundation. Tickets, $250, from (646) 230-9564.    For Child Welfare  WEDNESDAY -- The child welfare programs of Graham Windham Services for Families and Children, which is celebrating 200 years of service in New York, will benefit from a black-tie dinner at Cipriani Wall Street, 55 Wall Street (Hanover Street). Cocktails begin at 6:30. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 529-6445, ext. 316.    Children of Bellevue  WEDNESDAY -- Tom Colicchio and other New York chefs will cook specialty dishes from their restaurants for a tasting dinner at the Mandarin Oriental to raise money for Children of Bellevue, a group that supports pediatric programs at Bellevue Hospital Center. Cocktails begin at 7. Tickets, $400, or $225 for entry after 7:30, from (212) 562-4130.    Hale House Dinner  WEDNESDAY -- A black-tie dinner at Pier 60, Chelsea Piers, will raise money for the programs of Hale House Center, which provides care for children as well as transitional housing, an early-childhood learning center and other programs to help families. Cocktails begin at 6:30. Tickets, $500, from (212) 838-2660, ext. 14.    A Garden Party  WEDNESDAY -- The annual black-tie gala in the gardens of Wave Hill will raise money for its horticultural and educational programs. Drinks begin at 7, with dancing to the music of Peter Duchin and his ensemble. Tickets, $500, from (718) 549-3200, ext. 233.    Purple With a Purpose  THURSDAY -- Gloria Steinem will be a host of dinner at the Mandarin Oriental to benefit the Ms. Foundation for Women and its grant and educational programs. Cocktails at 6, with a performance of a song from ''The Color Purple'' by Kenita R. Miller. Tickets, $600, from (212) 709-4439.    Aiding Musical Talent  MAY 31 -- André Previn will be honored at a dinner at the Mandarin Oriental to raise money for the Kaufman Center, which includes a public school for musically talented students as well as Merkin Concert Hall and arts and music instruction. Cocktails at 6. Tickets, $700, from (212) 501-3350.    Alzheimer's Dinner  MAY 31 -- Dominic Chianese will be honored at the annual spring dinner dance to aid the Alzheimer's Association and the research and services it supports, at the Pierre. Cocktails begin at 6:30, with dancing to the music of Valerie Romanoff and the Starlight Orchestra. Tickets, $750, from (212) 983-6906, ext. 221.    For Sloan-Kettering  MAY 31 -- A black-tie dinner and dance at the Rainbow Room will aid the research, patient care and public education programs of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Cocktails begin at 7. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 874-5457. abstract: PERSKY--Mary E. (Betty). Passed away January 27, 2006 at Arden Courts in Tampa. Betty came to Tampa in 2003 after residing in Naples for several years. She moved to Naples from Pepper Pike, Ohio in 1986 with her late husband, Dr. Lester Persky. She was predeceased by her husband, her parents Mike and Catharine Connor and her sisters Peg McGahuey and Frances Armstrong. She is survived by her children: sons Dr. David Persky (Mary) of Tampa, Dr. James Persky (Cindy) of Cleveland, Ohio; daughter Katherine Persky of New York City; grandchildren Zachary, Paige, Rachel, Allison and Abigail and several nieces and nephews. A native of New Jersey, Betty attended Catholic school in Elizabeth and went on to obtain her nursing degree at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York. She served in the U.S. Navy during World War II as a Navy nurse and was honorably discharged. She used her GI Bill benefits to complete her college education at Boston University and settled down to raise her family after relocating to Cleveland, Ohio. As her children grew, Betty returned to nursing for several years as the school nurse at Hathaway Brown School in Shaker Heights. The family extends their sincere thanks to the staff of Arden Courts, LifePath Hospice and VC Family Staffing for their efforts in the care of Betty. The family will receive friends at Hunter's Green Country Club from 6:30 to 8:30 P.M. on Tuesday, January 31. A memorial service will be held in Cleveland, Ohio at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a charitable donation to the Alzheimer's Support Network of Naples, Florida, LifePath Hospice or a charitable organization of your own choosing.

abstract: Brain health programs are spreading across US, offering possibility of helping aging baby boomers postpone or avert memory loss or dementia; benefits of brain exercises have not been scientifically proven, but many mental health experts say even if brain health programs do not improve mind they are not harmful; appeal of programs is strong and many assisted living centers are promoting 'brain fitness'; few scientists believe brain health activities prevent dementia, but contend they may delay it; some experts say even if there is little cognitive benefit, there may be psychic benefit to mental exercises; photos (M)

abstract: CONNERAT--George H. Formerly of Essex, CT died peacefully on January 4, 2006 at the age of 94. For the past two years he resided in Berke ley Heights, NJ. Mr. Connerat the second son of Robert Vincent and Katherine was born on August 30, 1911 in Atlanta, GA. He was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of the University of Georgia in 1932, Harvard Business School in 1934 and George Washington Law School in 1937. From 1934 to 1940 he was a financial analyst for The Reconstruction Finance Corp. In WWII he served in the Quartermaster Corps rising to the rank of major. After the war, he began a long and distinguished career in the NY Metro area. From 1946 to 1952, he was the VP of Finance of Telecoin Corp. in New York City. He then became Treasurer of Republic Aviation Corp from 1952 to 1964. From 1964 to 1966, he was VP of Finance at Lehigh Valley Industries in New York City. From 1966 to 1974, he rose from VP to the position of President and CEO of Valley Metallurgical Processing Company of Essex, CT. He was an avid boater and tennis player. He was a member of the Old Lyme Country Club, The Harvard Club, The Skytop Club and The Strathmore Vanderbilt Country Club. Surviving him are his wife of 60 years Virginia Reed Hopper Connerat, their daughter Robin, son George and his wife Jeanne and their children Kristen and Elizabeth, also surviving are nieces Marianne Connerat Kendell and Jean Connerat Levine, daughters of his late brother Vincent. A memorial service will be held on Saturday January 14, 2006 at 1:30PM at Central Presbyterian Church, 70 Maple St., Summit, NJ 07901. Interment will be at a later date in the Connerat Family plot in Bonaventure Cemetery in Savannah, GA. Donations in memory of Mr. Connerat may be made to the Alzheimer's Association of NJ, 400 Morris Ave., Denville, NJ 07834. www.alznj.org

abstract: You just can't separate mystery and place. If the fictional Kurt Wallander lived in New York or London, he would still be the kind of tortured detective whom readers and viewers identify with. He's divorced, he drinks, his father has Alzheimer's disease, and he often wonders unhappily what the world is coming to. His only pleasure, it sometimes seems, is listening to opera in his police car. But there's something about Wallander's base of operations -- Ystad, Sweden, a small Baltic seaside town near Malmo -- that colors him gloomy and adds a satisfyingly gray touch to the mysteries he investigates. It may also help explain his total lack of humor. Beginning on Wednesday night and running through July 13, the American Scandinavian Foundation is screening ''Henning Mankell's Kurt Wallander Mysteries,'' four 90-minute television films, written by Mr. Mankell, the author of the internationally best-selling Wallander novels. (Keep in mind that Ingmar Bergman has done some of his best work, including ''Scenes From a Marriage,'' for Swedish television.) The murders that Wallander (Krister Henriksson) investigates include those of a wealthy couple found in their grand home, of an African man whose body is found on a train and of an American tourist visiting a famous Swedish photographer. (Above, Johanna Sallstrom in the episode ''Mastermind.'') Then, on July 19, screenings of the 2005 Danish drama series ''Ornen'' (''The Eagle'') begin. That show, which won an International Emmy Award, stars Jens Albinus as Hallgrim Orn Hallgrimsson, an Icelandic-born police inspector whose specialties appear to be international organized crime and existential crises. (The series runs through Aug. 10. Scandinavia House, 58 Park Avenue, between 37th and 38th Streets, 212-879-9779; $8.)    ANITA GATES

snippet: CONNERAT--George H.Formerly of Essex, CT died peacefully on January 4, 2006 at the age of 94. For the past two years he resided in Berke ley Heights, NJ. Mr. Connerat the second son of Robert Vincent and Katherine was born on August 30, 1911 in At...
lead_paragraph: CONNERAT--George H.Formerly of Essex, CT died peacefully on January 4, 2006 at the age of 94. For the past two years he resided in Berke ley Heights, NJ. Mr. Connerat the second son of Robert Vincent and Katherine was born on August 30, 1911 in Atlanta, GA. He was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of the University of Georgia in 1932, Harvard Business School in 1934 and George Washington Law School in 1937. From 1934 to 1940 he was a financial analyst for The Reconstruction Finance Corp. In WWII he served in the Quartermaster Corps rising to the rank of major. After the war, he began a long and distinguished career in the NY Metro area. From 1946 to 1952, he was the VP of Finance of Telecoin Corp. in New York City. He then became Treasurer of Republic Aviation Corp from 1952 to 1964. From 1964 to 1966, he was VP of Finance at Lehigh Valley Industries in New York City. From 1966 to 1974, he rose from VP to the position of President and CEO of Valley Metallurgical Processing Company of Essex, CT. He was an avid boater and tennis player. He was a member of the Old Lyme Country Club, The Harvard Club, The Skytop Club and The Strathmore Vanderbilt Country Club. Surviving him are his wife of 60 years Virginia Reed Hopper Connerat, their daughter Robin, son George and his wife Jeanne and their children Kristen and Elizabeth, also surviving are nieces Marianne Connerat Kendell and Jean Connerat Levine, daughters of his late brother Vincent. A memorial service will be held on Saturday January 14, 2006 at 1:30PM at Central Presbyterian Church, 70 Maple St., Summit, NJ 07901. Interment will be at a later date in the Connerat Family plot in Bonaventure Cemetery in Savannah, GA. Donations in memory of Mr. Connerat may be made to the Alzheimer's Association of NJ, 400 Morris Ave., Denville, NJ 07834. www.alznj.org

abstract: Department of Education employee Sandra McMikle is charged with grand larceny for allegedly stealing about $116,000 from special education program by submitting fraudulent claims for services (S)
snippet: Department of Education employee Sandra McMikle is charged with grand larceny for allegedly stealing about $116,000 from special education program by submitting fraudulent claims for services (S)
lead_paragraph: A city employee was arrested yesterday on charges of grand larceny, accused of stealing about $116,000 from a special education program, officials said. The employee, Sandra McMikle, who has worked for the Department of Education for about 25 years, was assigned to process reimbursement claims for transportation and other supplemental education services. From 2001 to this year, she submitted more than 40 fraudulent claims for services to a fictitious child, investigators said. The claims identified Ms. McMikle's mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's disease, as the person to be reimbursed for expenses on behalf of the fictitious child, investigators said. Ms. McMikle told investigators that she had "tried it once to see if it would work," then began submitting claims regularly, a report said. The city paid the claims until January, when Ms. McMikle's colleagues became suspicious of awkward wording and obsolete case numbers in the documents, the report said. Ms. McMikle told investigators that her mother was unaware of the fraudulent claims, the report said. She pleaded not guilty at her arraignment yesterday. A spokeswoman for the Department of Education, Kelly Devers, said, "We are taking appropriate steps to terminate her employment." MICHAEL BRICK (NYT)

abstract: Josephine Tesauro never thought she would live so long. At 92, she is straight backed, firm jawed and vibrantly healthy, living alone in an immaculate brick ranch house high on a hill near McKeesport, a Pittsburgh suburb. She works part time in a hospital gift shop and drives her 1995 white Oldsmobile Cutlass Ciera to meetings of her four bridge groups, to church and to the grocery store. She has outlived her husband, who died nine years ago, when he was 84. She has outlived her friends, and she has outlived three of her six brothers.     Mrs. Tesauro does, however, have a living sister, an identical twin. But she and her twin are not so identical anymore. Her sister is incontinent, she has had a hip replacement, and she has a degenerative disorder that destroyed most of her vision. She also has dementia. ''She just does not comprehend,'' Mrs. Tesauro says.

abstract: LEE--Joseph A. Jr. of Carmel, CA, died on Wednesday, November 1, at the age of 84. Joe Lee was born in 1921, in Evanston, IL, and raised in Greenwich, CT, the only child of Joseph A. and Barbara (Senseney) Lee of Deer Park in Greenwich. He attended The Greenwich Country Day School, Hotchkiss, Yale University and the Harvard Business School. During World War II he served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Army Air Corps. Following graduation he entered into the investment business in New York City with Union Securities Corp. in 1948. From there he went to the Reynolds Co where he was a manager of the institutional department and then on to Bankers Trust Co where he served as Vice President and Deputy Director of investment research. From 1966 to 1976 he worked for Rockefeller Family and Associates as Senior Investment Advisor. In 1976 he semi-retired to Carmel with his wife Barbara (Burnham), where he became involved with numerous charitable, civic and business interests, and pursued his lifelong love of golf at Cypress Point Club and The Monterey Peninsula Country Club. Through the years he remained consistently himself: a devoted husband; a loving father and grandfather; a loyal and generous friend; a passionate golfer; and a deeply interested observer of current events, especially in the fields of business, finance, politics and sports. He is survived by his wife, Barbara B. Lee, of Pebble Beach; a daughter, Linda L. Smith, of El Cerrito, CA; three sons, Donald P. Lee of Boston, MA; Allen C. Lee of Tucson, AZ; Andrew S. Lee of San Rafael, CA; a son-in-law, Robert Smith; two daughtersin-law, Nancy J. Lee and Sandra P. Lee; four grandchildren, Rachel Lee, Joe Lee, Leeland Smith and Elijah Smith; a step-grandson, Jason Hammer; a step-daughter-in-law, Katherine H. Hammer; and a step-great-granddaughter, Eleanor. A memorial service will be held at 1 pm, on Monday, November 6, 2006, at The Mission Mortuary, 450 Camino El Estero, Monterey, CA; (831) 375-4129. A reception will follow. In lieu of flowers gifts can be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 182 El Dorado Street, Monterey, CA 93940.
